prior_works.title: Causality: Models, Reasoning, and Inference
prior_works.role: Foundational causal theory; formalizes counterfactual semantics and probabilities of causation (PN, PS, PNS).
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This paper’s core idea of optimizing for the probability of necessary and sufficient causation directly builds on Pearl’s formal definition of PNS and its counterfactual semantics.

prior_works.title: Probabilities of Causation: Bounds and Identification
prior_works.role: Identification and bounding results for PN/PS/PNS from observational and interventional data.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The proposed PNS risk and its practical surrogates are informed by Tian and Pearl’s results on how PNS can be bounded/approximated from data under assumptions.

prior_works.title: Causal inference using invariant prediction: identification and confidence intervals
prior_works.authors: Jonas Peters, Peter Bühlmann, Nicolai Meinshausen
prior_works.role: Introduces invariant causal prediction (ICP), formalizing invariance of causal mechanisms across environments for OOD generalization.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper extends the invariance principle of ICP by arguing that invariance alone can select necessary-but-insufficient features and thus must be complemented with PNS to ensure predictive sufficiency.

prior_works.title: Invariant Risk Minimization
prior_works.authors: Martin Arjovsky, Léon Bottou, Ishaan Gulrajani, David Lopez-Paz
prior_works.role: Optimization framework enforcing invariant predictors across environments for OOD generalization.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: IRM provides the main learning paradigm the authors critique and build upon, replacing pure invariance constraints with a PNS-based objective to avoid relying on insufficient yet stable features.

prior_works.title: Out-of-Distribution Generalization via Risk Extrapolation (REx)
prior_works.authors: David Krueger, Ethan Caballero, Joern-Henrik Jacobsen, Amy Zhang, Jonathan Binas, Roger Grosse, Aaron Courville
prior_works.role: Objective that equalizes risks across environments to encourage invariance and robustness.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: REx motivates the need to control environment-specific variation, while the new work refines the target by explicitly favoring causes that are both necessary and sufficient via PNS rather than risk equalization alone.

prior_works.title: Distributionally Robust Neural Networks for Group Shifts (GroupDRO)
prior_works.authors: Shiori Sagawa, Pang Wei Koh, Tatsunori B. Hashimoto, Percy Liang
prior_works.role: Distributionally robust optimization for worst-case group risk under domain shifts.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: GroupDRO frames robustness as worst-case risk minimization, which the paper complements by proposing PNS risk that aligns robustness with causal sufficiency and necessity, reducing reliance on spurious but robust shortcuts.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s central innovation is to recast OOD generalization as selecting features that are simultaneously necessary and sufficient causes for the target, operationalized through the Probability of Necessity and Sufficiency (PNS). This leverages Judea Pearl’s counterfactual framework and the formal definition of probabilities of causation (PN, PS, PNS), providing the conceptual backbone for measuring whether a feature truly causes the outcome rather than correlates with it. Building on Tian and Pearl’s identification and bounding results, the authors motivate how PNS can be approximated from available data and encoded into a practical learning objective (PNS risk).

On the OOD side, the work responds to the invariance paradigm inaugurated by ICP and made algorithmic by IRM and REx: while these methods seek predictors stable across environments, they can overemphasize necessary-but-insufficient features that remain invariant yet lack discriminative power, or sufficient-but-unnecessary features that overfit to specific domains. GroupDRO strengthens robustness via worst-case risk minimization, but still lacks a causal criterion for selecting which stable features to trust. By integrating PNS into the objective, the paper unifies invariance with a causal sufficiency-necessity criterion, explicitly favoring features that both persist across environments (necessity) and determine the label (sufficiency). This synthesis yields a principled alternative to invariance-only or robustness-only formulations, aligning OOD generalization with counterfactual causation and providing a learning signal directly tied to the desired causal property.
